content.title: Arterial (Ischemic) Ulcer
content.definition: Open skin defect resulting from inadequate arterial blood supply to meet tissue oxygen demands, characterized by punched-out appearance, pale wound base, distal location, and severe pain. Represents the most severe presentation of peripheral arterial disease and requires revascularization for healing.

key_concepts.description: Critical reduction in arterial perfusion below tissue oxygen requirements; often precipitated by minor trauma, pressure, or ill-fitting footwear in setting of severe PAD; unable to mount healing response
Distal extremity - toes, heel, foot, lateral malleolus; pressure points; between toes; over bony prominences. NOT in gaiter zone (venous territory)
Punched-out, well-demarcated edges; pale/yellow necrotic or grey base (no granulation tissue); deep, may expose tendon/bone; small size relative to symptoms; dry
Severe pain out of proportion to ulcer size; worsened by elevation (opposite of venous); often requires opioids; may have associated rest pain; pain relief with dependency
Shiny, atrophic skin; hair loss; thickened dystrophic nails; pallor with elevation; dependent rubor; cool temperature; absent or diminished pulses
Typically ABI <0.5; toe pressure <30 mmHg; TcPO2 <30 mmHg. May have falsely elevated ABI with calcified vessels (diabetes, ESRD) - use toe pressures
Arterial ulcers will NOT heal without revascularization; wound care alone is futile; intervention (endovascular or surgical bypass) is primary treatment, not wound dressings
Uses Wound, Ischemia, and foot Infection grades (0-3 each) to predict amputation risk and revascularization benefit; high ischemia grade indicates need for revascularization
Without revascularization, major amputation rate approaches 50% at 1 year; revascularization reduces risk but healing may take months even with adequate perfusion
After successful revascularization, wound healing begins; may require debridement, off-loading, moisture balance; healing time depends on wound size and comorbidities

learning_objectives: Identify characteristic features of arterial ulcers
Understand that revascularization is required for healing
Recognize the futility of wound care alone without addressing blood supply
clinical_pearls: Distal, punched-out, painful, pale base = arterial
Medial malleolus, shallow, less painful, granulating = venous
Pain worse with elevation = arterial (opposite of venous)
No revascularization = no healing for arterial ulcers
ABI may be falsely normal in diabetes - use toe pressures
Wound care without revascularization is futile in arterial ulcers
common_mistakes: Treating with wound care alone without vascular assessment
Relying on ABI in diabetic/ESRD patients with calcification
